awd_titl_txt: Youth Participatory Science to Address Urban Heavy Metal Contamination
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This project is focused on the work and learning of teachers as they engage youth from underrepresented groups in studying chemistry as a subject relevant to heavy metal contamination in their neighborhoods. The project is a collaboration of teachers in the Chicago Public Schools, science educators, chemists, and environmental scientists from the University of Illinois at Chicago, Northwestern University, Loyola University, and members of the Chicago Environmental Justice Network. The project is significant because it leverages existing partnerships and builds on pilot projects which will be informed by a corresponding cycle of research on teachers' learning and practice. The project will position Chicago teachers and students as Change Makers who are capable of addressing the crises of inequity in science education and environmental contamination that matter deeply to them, while simultaneously advancing their own understanding and expertise. The project will examine the malleable factors affecting the ability of teachers to engage underrepresented students in innovative urban citizen science projects with a focus on the synergistic learning that occurs as teachers, students, scientists, and community members work together on addressing complex socio-scientific issues. 

The goal is to provide a network of intellectual and analytical support to high school chemistry teachers engaged in customizing curricula in response to urban environmental concerns. The project will use an annual summer institute where collaborators will develop curriculum and procedures for collecting soil and water samples. In the project, the teachers and students will work with university scientists to analyze these samples for heavy metals, and students will share their results in community settings. The study design will be multiple case and be used to study the content knowledge learned and mobilized by participating teachers as they develop these authentic projects. The project includes explicit focus on the professional development of high school science teachers while it also aims to create rich learning opportunities for underrepresented high school students in STEM fields. The contextualized science concepts within students' everyday experiences or socio-scientific issues will likely have a positive impact on student motivation and learning outcomes, but the experiences of urban students are less likely to be reflected by the curriculum, and the practices of effective secondary science teachers in these contexts are under-examined.

por.por_cntn:
Our project focused on supporting a group of teachers to lead authentic scientific projects about issues of environmental justice in their school communities. These projects had several broader impacts related to community engagement, educational trajectories of students, and teacher professional development. Our educational research about these projects has focused on teacher professional learning and has made unique contributions of intellectual merit to the fields of science education and teacher education. 

With respect to community engagement, students who participated in the project presented to local officials and spoke to their neighbors about issues of heavy metal contamination in their communities. In one example, high school students presented to the leadership of the school district about soil contamination in a potential school garden site. Their presentation led to the installation of an indoor hydroponic garden in their school, and they received a civic engagement award from the Obama Foundation and Chicago Public Schools for this work. In another example, middle school students presented to their city council representative. Their presentation, coupled with a related community report produced by project leaders, led to the remediation of lead-based paint on four viaducts in the neighborhood. Another group of high school students led a door-knocking campaign in their community to encourage their neighbors to participate in a city program to test drinking water for lead contamination. With respect to educational trajectories, hundreds of high school students had the opportunity to conduct and present scientific research at a university campus and two high school students became co-presenters and co-authors of an academic book chapter. We anticipate that these sorts of experiences will continue to have a positive impact on the educational trajectories of participating students.

With respect to teacher professional development, participating teachers presented at numerous professional conferences and contributed as co-authors to practitioner-oriented and academic publications. Several participating teachers were thrust into leadership roles, including two who became STEM instructional coaches at their school and one who led project-based learning at the district level. Two participating teachers have shifted to careers in educational research and continue to study youth participatory science in those trajectories. Several other participating teachers have stayed in the classroom and will continue to lead YPS projects beyond the scope of the project.

In our educational research about supporting YPS projects in secondary science classrooms, we identified some challenges and opportunities with respect to aligning community-oriented science education with the Next Generation Science Standards or NGSS. We have also described how teaching about the concepts and principles underlying the functioning of scientific instruments can be a link between NGSS and social justice issues. To support classroom projects, we developed a youth participatory science curriculum framework, and we have shared examples of YPS projects that successfully bridged science learning and civic engagement. We have articulated the features of a participatory process for determining the priorities of professional learning with content area teachers. We have disseminated these results in academic, practitioner, and community settings.
